summary:
Scientific Lead of 510 an initiative of The Netherlands Red Cross. His research concerns improving preparedness and response to both natural hazards and complex emergencies through predictive analytics using small and big data, disaster and climate risk management, information management and coordination mechanisms. Advisory board member WMO The High-Impact Weather Project (HIWeather), IFRCs Early Action Protocol Validation Committee, Valorisation panel NWO project Disastrous Information: embedding “Do No Harm” principles into innovative geo-intelligence workflows for effective humanitarian action, NWO user’s committee Veni grant Bridging the gap between Artificial Intelligence and society: Developing responsible and viable solutions for geospatial data and Global Steering Committee, Preparing Actionable Data for Inclusive Shelter (ELRAH project)

Marc has multiple short and mid-term field experiences in Africa (Botswana, Burundi, Burkina Faso, Democratic Republic of Congo, Lesotho, Mali, Malawi, Niger, South Africa and Zambia) and Asia (Bangladesh, India, Nepal, The Philippines and Vietnam). 

Former leader and co-founder within TNO, the Netherlands Research and Technology Organization, of the ICT for Development (ICT4D) team with which he implemented pro-poor ICT innovations for sustainable social and economic development in emerging countries by developing projects in partnership with international organizations, public authorities, NGOs, private foundations, private sector partners and social entrepreneurs. Former technical team member of the NATO Research and Technology Group 248 on Social Media and Information Technology for Disaster and Crisis Response.  

Marc holds the disaster management certificate from the International Federation of Red Cross Red Crescent Societies/Tata Institute of Social Sciences, an MBA from the Rotterdam School of Management (with a specialization in entrepreneurship in emerging economies) and a PhD in physics from Delft University of Technology.  Marc started his career at the R&D department of the incumbent operator in the Netherlands, KPN. Marc has lived and worked in Belgium, Germany, France (four years) and the US.

Publications: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Marc_Van_Den_Homberg

Specialties and interests: Big data and Artificial Intelligence for Disaster Risk Management, Impact-based forecasting, People-Centered Early Warning Systems, Local Knowledge, Multi-hazard and consecutive events, ICT4D

profile_positions.description:
•	Define key research directions for 510 themes (anticipatory action, emergency support, cash based assistance, digital transformation and Water and landscape (Nature-based solutions)) 
•	Setting up collaborations and partnerships with universities and knowledge institutes. 
•	External supervisor of around 10 MSc students and interns per year and collaboration with on average 4 PhD students 
•	Technical expertise for projects, developing materials and guidelines, defining methodologies, sharing lessons learned, documentation and reporting. Principal author for key project deliverables. 
•	(Co)-authoring peer-reviewed articles and reviewer for journals. 
•	Organizing sessions and presenting at conferences such as scientific conferences or Multi-hazard Early Warning Systems WMO conference or UNDRR’s Global Platform for DRR.   
•	Teaching and giving training to Red Cross National Societies and external guest lectures at for example IHE, VU Amsterdam, ITC Enschede, Tilburg University (Netherlands), Ecole des Mines IMT Alès (France). 
•	Identifying opportunities and proposal development with key partners for donors such as EU ECHO/Horizon 2020, GFDRR, Global Partnership for Sustainable Development Data, UNDRR, World Bank, German/French/Danish Red Cross, and Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

profile_positions.description:
Humanitarian Data and Data for Development: 
•	Delivered consultancy with Dalberg for UN OCHA and Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs on a vision for and the feasibility of an entity to improve the use of data across the humanitarian ecosystem. 
•	With Peace Informatics Lab, New York University (GovLab) performed a risk analysis for UN OCHA on data policies for their main IT systems. 

Humanitarian Information Management: 
•	Participated as team member Disaster Resilience Lab in innovative field-research in The Philippines one month after Typhoon Haiyan.
•	Towards a Balkans’ Data for Disaster Management Collaborative? Lecturer NATO Center of Excellence Crisis Management and Disaster Response; Advanced Research Working group Implications of Climate Change and Disasters on Military Activities: Building Resilience and Mitigating Risks and Vulnerability in Balkans. 

Social media for disasters and crisis response:
•	Technical team member NATO Research and Technology Group HFM 248 Social Media and IT for Disaster and Crisis Response. Provided technical demonstration of social media monitoring capabilities, potential metrics for understanding discourses in social media in NATO exercise. Researched added value big data for disaster management in high data poverty context with social media (SCRAAWL, TweetTracker) + digital volunteerism analysis.
profile_positions.title: Independent researcher and consultant

profile_positions.description:
Strategic guidance and expert technology advice on creating innovative Disaster Risk Reduction and Disaster Response approaches using modern and innovative technology. Data-driven development of people-centered early warning system: leveraging ICT and (big) data to close last mile information gap and to strengthen multi-stakeholder cooperation. 

•	Developing data-driven cross border community based early warning system in India and Nepal and in Bangladesh. Co-created partnerships with governmental organizations such as Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief in Bangladesh, with regional institutes such as Regional Integrated Multi-Hazard Early Warning System for Africa and Asia and with national and local NGOs. 
•	Provided input on multi-hazard early warning systems to Asia Regional Plan for Implementation of the Sendai Framework at the Nov 2016 AMCDRR conference.
•	Lecturer on Data Preparedness in Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) on Science and Technology for DRR, UNESCO Cooperation & Development Center (CODEV) at the École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) (2016).
•	Supervised research with Utrecht University into applying data science to bridge information gaps by determining decision maker’s information needs, mapping data sets on these needs and linking disparate data sets (2015-2016). 
•	Attended as an international observer the Dibrugarh Emergency Management Exercise on invitation of National Disaster Management Authority of India (2014). 
•	Participated in innovative field-research in The Philippines one month after the Typhoon Haiyan with Disaster Resilience Lab (2013).
